title: I strongly believe mage items now have problems and lack of variety.
body:
First on, I simply adore mages. I like their playstyle their drawbacks and strengths. But, when I play other classes I find that the itemizations are very unflexible. While ADCs have bork, or IE. Toplaners have hydra or cleaver. A normal mage core build is almost locked into place with no flexibility. As saying, its a huge ball of AP on top of AP without unique stats aside from mana regen.
The largest culprits are.

{{item:3165}} {{item:3135}} 

Another problem is that there is WAY too much cooldown reduction, that it is now a spamfest on top of spamfests. (Like how the hell leblanc can Q and Q and proc mark around 35% cdr? ) Cooldowns were a large factor of actually exploiting an enemys opening and now it is not much of a thing anymore. Actually there is so much CDR that there can even be a option of a item of REDUCING cdr at this point.

Another thing that needs to be looked at is the hextech items. They were supposed to fill up playstyles and niches. Which was a clever idea. was supposed to be amp item like RFC, ruunans, shiv, PD for adcs.
...the problem was that they were TOO niche. I cant recall anyone buying GLP, gunblade is used to exploit damage coverage rather than sustain. Had to admit protobelt is nice though. This has been said on this board several times, please consider creating hextech items for sheen users, mage assassins, and battle mages.

Edit:
I hear a lot of players complaining about mages these days. And I also believe that it is valid. Since the builds offer no actual drawback and it is the best of the best of statballiness snowball. We can change this, you know but a few factors must be changed, tweaked and revised and open up new bridges for variety here.

I was going to write a short comment about how to fix this; turned out not to be so short and better suited for a full post of its own. I'll link you if/when I get around to it.

tl;dr, ideally, mages should have the equivalent of {{item:3086}}: A bundle of stats that everyone wants, that gives you flexibility in how you'll build when you finish it into a complete item. Problem is, it's hard to make such an item, because there's no stat that is the AP equivalent to crit (ie, all carries and only carries want it).

AP itemization actually acknowledges this; in a lot of ways, {{item:3165}} is the equivalent of {{item:3086}} , but instead of "what does this build into", it's "what do I build next?" It's functional, but not very interesting for the player.

I don't have time to type a huge post about it, but the reason Mage items are "Stale" or boring compared to AD items is simply because Mages variety is in their kit, not their items. Every ADC Right clicks, for the most part, so their itemization is meant to help differentiate in how they Right Click. Mages are already varied enough in the different champions that their itemization doesn't need to help make them different. 

They're the Unique [Salt and Straw ](http://saltandstraw.com/flavors/) as compared to AD's "Pick your topping" Cold Stone.

{{item:3030}} works well on {{champion:136}} {{champion:74}} {{champion:50}} and maybe {{champion:13}} 
That's about it.

I don't know how many times it will have to be pointed out, but the community (read: boards and Reddit) BEGGED for more CDR prior to the mage update. The necessity of runes to accommodate it before was always a huge argument, because it was needed to reach the cap. Now all of a sudden the wish is granted and it's a problem?

Gee, it's like there are different mindsets on the boards and we aren't some sort of hivemind. People who wanted CDR are likely happy and content, no longer having a reason to voice themselves. People who didn't want more CDR are now the ones making themselves heard.
So where was this crowd when the buffs were asked for? Silent? I saw a general consensus, not a naysay in sight, some which are the very same names I see now who are saying there's too much.

AP itemization has been in a garbage state for a VERY long time, I remember writing a detailed post about it on the old boards all the way back in season 3. There's a bunch of problems, and part of the problem isn't items themselves but the archetype as a whole being problematic. (Ex: how many mages out there are built around the idea of dumping their entire spell rotation immediately for maximum burst? Answer: A lot of them.)
{{item:3165}} has been a 1-stop shop for everything mages want from a 1st item for a long time, before it, in season 3, we had {{item:3174}} before they reworked that into a support item and decided mages aren't allowed to have good mana regeneration and must rely on having a deep mana pool if they experience significant mana costs (not really a bad change, also not one that really helps either, though it does make engineering non-abusable component items a bit easier if that pattern is in place). Some mages that don't need CDR and really want some tank stats because they're short range or do damage over time may pick up {{item:3027}} first instead (ex: {{champion:1}}, {{champion:30}}, {{champion:50}} etc.) But if you value CDR, then, {{item:3165}} is a no-brainer. If it's AP was 80, and there was a different {{item:3802}} derived item that was more built around the idea of lane dominance and aggressive play which actually gives 100 AP, but isn't a 20% CDR item (maybe 10% or none at all), it would probably help alleviate {{item:3165}}'s prevalence.

Void Staff could probably use the the {{item:3035}} treatment, and this would also allow {{item:3165}} to lose Grevious Wounds, but still allow AP to appropriately counter-build powerful sustain champs (this is why {{item:3033}} exists for AD in addition to {{item:3036}}). There isn't enough flat magic penetration items in the game {{item:3020}} and {{item:3151}} (I don't count {{item:3136}} separately because it's just a component, that builds into {{item:3151}}), especially now that ranged champs actually get .5 MR/level, and things like {{item:3139}}, and {{item:3814}} are actually decently common buys on squishy AD champs. I think having an AP component similar to {{item:3134}} that builds into 2-3 different magic pen items would go a LONG way towards solving this problem (note that I think no one item should give more than 15 flat magic pen, no more than 10 from the proposed component, since MR values are usually still lower than armor, and people need armor to tank tower shots/jungle monsters).
